basics.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
basics.label: Universal Genius & Last Renaissance Man
basics.summary: Polymath extraordinaire with expertise in mathematics, philosophy, theology, law, and diplomacy. Inventor of calculus (yes, before Newton published), binary system visionary, and creator of the concept of possible worlds. Passionate about unifying all human knowledge and settling disputes through rational calculation.

work.name: House of Hanover
work.summary: Primary intellectual advisor to the Dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg and later the Elector of Hanover.
highlights: Maintained the ducal library with obsessive precision
Wrote family genealogy tracing Hanover lineage to Italian nobility
Provided mathematical consultation on mining operations
Diplomatically advised on succession matters (helped secure British throne for Hanover)

work.name: University of Altdorf
work.summary: Completed doctorate in law at age 20, declined professorship offer because the world was too big to settle down.
highlights: Youngest doctoral graduate in university history
Dissertation on legal reasoning impressed faculty so much they offered immediate tenure
Politely declined to pursue broader intellectual adventures

work.name: Baron von Boineburg's Service
work.summary: Served influential German statesman while developing early philosophical and mathematical ideas.
highlights: Drafted legal documents by day, revolutionized mathematics by night
Proposed unification of Christian churches (ambitious side project)
Designed early calculating machine to automate 'unworthy' arithmetic tasks

work.name: French Court (Unofficial)
work.summary: Attempted to convince Louis XIV to conquer Egypt instead of Europe (unsuccessful but educational).
highlights: Developed calculus while trying to distract French from German territories
Met with leading mathematicians and philosophers of Paris
Learned that even brilliant mathematical arguments can't redirect royal ambitions

volunteer.summary: Founded and led scientific academy to advance human knowledge across all disciplines.
highlights: Convinced Elector Frederick III that Prussia needed its own scientific academy
Established academy motto: 'Theory and Practice'
Promoted international scientific collaboration despite ongoing European wars

volunteer.summary: Lifelong effort to reunite Christian churches through rational dialogue.
highlights: Corresponded with Catholic, Lutheran, and Reformed theologians
Argued that doctrinal differences were mostly semantic misunderstandings
Maintained hope despite consistent evidence to the contrary

education.score: Summa Cum Laude (invented new categories of excellence)

courses: The Art of Making Everything Mathematical

awards.title: Fellow of the Royal Society of London
awards.summary: Elected for mathematical innovations, despite ongoing calculus priority dispute with Newton.

awards.title: Foreign Member of the French Academy of Sciences
awards.summary: International recognition for contributions to mathematics and natural philosophy.

awards.title: Inventor of Calculus (Co-Title, Disputed)
awards.summary: First to publish calculus notation still used today, though Newton claims earlier invention.

publications.name: Discourse on Metaphysics
publications.summary: Outlined theory of individual substances and best of all possible worlds.

publications.name: New Essays on Human Understanding
publications.summary: Point-by-point response to Locke's Essay, defending innate ideas and rationalism.

publications.name: Theodicy
publications.summary: Defended God's justice in permitting evil; coined 'best of all possible worlds'.

publications.name: Monadology
publications.summary: 90 propositions explaining reality as composed of simple, indivisible monads.

references.name: Sir Isaac Newton
references.reference: A man of extraordinary genius, though we disagree on priority matters and the nature of space and time. His mathematical abilities are... adequate.

references.name: Sophie Charlotte of Hanover
references.reference: My most brilliant philosophical correspondent and pupil. Made the court infinitely more intellectually stimulating.

references.name: John Locke
references.reference: We fundamentally disagree on the nature of human understanding, but his commitment to rigorous analysis is admirable.

projects.name: Binary Number System
projects.description: Developed complete binary arithmetic system, connecting it to Chinese I Ching philosophy
highlights: Laid foundation for modern computer science
Saw theological significance in creation from nothing (0) and something (1)
Impressed Chinese Emperor with binary interpretation of ancient texts
